newsitem.title: FRANCE: Elf says in talks on Ecuador oil block.
newsitem.headline: Elf says in talks on Ecuador oil block.

text.p: Elf Aquitaine is discussing changes to one of its four oil contracts in Ecuador and is open to all ideas, a company spokesman said on Thursday.
The discussions focus on block 14, located in the central- eastern part of the country, and have been going on for four months, he said.
"We are open to all discussion and ways of revising the existing contract and we have been meeting regularly for four months," the spokesman said.

Elf is one of a number of foreign oil companies active in Ecuador, which said on Wednesday it planned to revise all foreign oil operations and banned a U.S. firm, Maxus Energy Corp, from drilling for oil.

Maxus, owned by Argentina's YPF SA, does not have a production-sharing deal with the Ecuadorean government under a regulation requiring that foreign firms grant the state at least 12.5 percent of output.
The Elf spokesman said block 14 was currently run as a "type of service contract" but that discussions could change this.
Two other blocks, Shiripuno and block 18, were already set up as production participation deals, he said.
A fourth, block 17, is still at the exploration stage and Elf announced what it called a significant oil discovery there in July.
Elf has been in Ecuador since 1987 and produces 3,500 barrels per day (bpd), the spokesman said. Ecuador produced about 395,000 bpd last year.
The company made no comment on Ecuador's latest declarations on foreign oil company interests.
President Abdala Bucaram, who was elected in July and calls himself the "president of the poor," ordered the drilling ban by Maxus until it agreed to joint ventures with the state oil firm.
Energy and Mining Minister Alfredo Adoum said he had issued orders for the army to take possession of the Maxus fields.
However in Buenos Aires, YPF president Nells Leon said its oil installations in Ecuador were operating normally and had not been taken over by the armed forces.
